headline: How to drive your car safely in snow and ice this winter
body: Here is the best advice to help you stay safe on the road in inclement weather this winter
content:
4. Pick the correct lights
Remember, you mustn’t use your fog lamps unless the visibility is very poor – rear fog lamps will dazzle other road users, and the effect is intensified when there is spray from melted snow coming out from the rear of the car. Front fog lamps have the same effect, but for cars ahead of you, especially when snow on the road is reflecting the light back up at them.
The Highway Code says that you should only use your fog lamps when the visibility drops below 100m. If you’re not sure when that is, a good rule of thumb is to work out whether you can see the tail lights of the car in front. If you can’t, you (and they) should be using rear fog lamps. However, if you can, you probably don’t need them.
Snow does not mean you need to use your main beam headlights any more or less often than you would normally. You shouldn’t leave them on when driving towards or behind other traffic, as it will dazzle those drivers.
If you’re in any doubt about which lights to use, put yourself in the position of other drivers around you. Ask yourself what your car looks like to them, whether they can see you and whether they might be blinded by any of your lights.
5. Keep your distance
Cast your mind back to your driving test, and you’ll remember that stopping distances increase in icy conditions. But can you remember by how much?
In actual fact, it can take as much as 10 times as long to stop on an icy road as it does on a dry one. If you can, you should increase the distance between you and the car you’re following by about that much.
A good rule of thumb is that you should be around 20 seconds behind the car in front of you if the road is icy. That way, if that car has to stop suddenly – or, worse still, crashes into a car in front – you will have time to stop, or take avoiding action.
To check you’re far enough away, watch for the car in front to pass an object – a lamp post, bridge or sign. Then count how many seconds go by before you pass the same object. If it’s under 20 seconds, you should back off and allow more space.
One of the main problems with this strategy is that not everybody is playing the same game. If you leave a 20-second gap between your car and the one in front, another car or van will probably try to fill that gap. Be aware of this and be prepared to give way to somebody driving antisocially.
6. Drive smoothly and gently
Driving in ice and snow isn’t just about leaving more space, though. It requires a very different driving style that relatively few people are aware of.
For starters, your use of all the controls – steering, accelerator and brake – should be as smooth, slow and progressive as you can make them. Abrupt changes in the car’s attitude will cause the tyres to lose what little grip on the road’s surface they have. That could lead to you skidding, spinning your wheels, or getting stuck before you’ve even pulled away.
In a manual car, move away slowly by slipping the clutch as gently as you can, keeping the engine revs low, and ensure you change gear early as you accelerate and late as you decelerate, again so that you keep the revs to a minimum. Lower revs mean the engine is turning more slowly, which reduces the risk of wheelspin.
If you’re driving an automatic or four-wheel-drive car, check to see whether it has a low-ratio mode. This can be indicated by a snowflake symbol or an ‘L’ on a switch near to the gear lever. If it has one of these, use it. You should avoid using Sport mode in an automatic car that’s so-equipped. Some automatic cars have a gearchange setting optimised for ice and snow, normally denoted by a snowflake icon; select this on ice and compacted snow.
At the same time, try to avoid using settings specifically for low-traction environments when driving on gritted or cleared tarmac. Certain mechanisms within the car could be put under undue strain when used in high-grip situations.
You should also try and avoid sudden manoeuvres that might unbalance the car, such as sharp steering or braking. Doing so increases the likelihood of your car skidding.
7. Learn how to deal with skidding
It is a good idea to gently test your brakes and steering now and again to get an idea of how slippery the road is. Obviously, you should pick a straight, clear piece of road away from any junctions, and make sure there’s nobody following you when you do so.
It’s also advisable to keep the volume of your radio turned down when driving on snow. Your ears can often give you the first warning that you’ve hit a slippery patch. Driving through snow patches will create more tyre noise than usual thanks to its crunching, as well as the roar of snow being kicked up into the wheel arches. Conversely, if the tyre noise suddenly goes quiet, that can mean you’re driving on a patch of ice.
If you hit a patch of slippery road and you feel the car start to skid, lift your foot off the accelerator and allow the speed to drop by itself until you regain control. Avoid using the brakes, as this will prolong the skid. If the car starts to spin while you are skidding, steer into the direction of the spin and allow the car to straighten up.

headline: Stokes wins battle with Labuschagne but England are losing the war again
body: Stokes wins battle with Labuschagne but England are losing the war again
content:
It was a small win on a day when familiar cracks re-emerged for England. But it is hard to know whether Ben Stokes’s sweary tirade at Marnus Labuschagne was just him unloading on one of the game’s more irritating opponents or if it was a coded message to his team.
Either way it seemed to fire up Stokes, who moments later dismissed Labuschagne for 48 to lift a woeful England bowling performance that threatened to undo all the hard work of Joe Root’s 41st Test century.
Once again it is Root and Stokes dragging this team along, lifting them out of the mire with bat and ball. Root’s 160 was a masterpiece of concentration and risk assessment in difficult batting conditions – a lesson in game management lost on younger colleagues. The weight of responsibility was so much that he spent most of the Australia innings off the field with a back spasm.

headline: Watch: Harrison Reed’s goal of the season pegs back Liverpool in dying seconds
body: Watch: Harrison Reed’s goal of the season pegs back Liverpool in dying seconds
content:
Almost 1,000 days have passed since Harrison Reed last experienced the delights of scoring a goal. For him and for Fulham, it was worth the wait. With this tense match against Liverpool entering its final seconds, the man known in these parts as the “ginger Iniesta” went for the old-school approach by simply smashing the ball towards goal from 25 yards.
What followed was the strike of a lifetime and surely the goal of the season in the Premier League. Reed’s shot scorched through the freezing afternoon air, travelling with truly outrageous power, and dipped into the top corner of Alisson Becker’s net at the last possible moment.
This was the least likely of goals, scored by the least likely of players. Before this game, Reed had not scored since April 2023. He had barely even played this season, clocking just six minutes of Premier League action all campaign.
“Total inspiration,” said Marco Silva, Fulham’s head coach. “I know he is not pleased with his game-time but he is a top professional, always pushing everybody forward. If someone deserves this type of incredible moment, Harrison for sure is one of them.”

headline: Chelsea’s rookie coach outwits Guardiola to dent Man City title hopes
body: Chelsea’s rookie coach outwits Guardiola to dent Man City title hopes
content:
Who would have thought that a rookie manager – who only seven months ago was a youth team coach at Southampton – would play such a potentially significant role in the Premier League title race?
This was the first game that Calum McFarlane has ever been in charge of a senior team. At any level. And he was up against no less than Pep Guardiola, the greatest coach of his generation, who has been in the technical area for 1,012 matches.
It might the first and the last for McFarlane although the way he coached Chelsea and the way he spoke afterwards suggests otherwise. He looks like one to watch.
Not least because the enduring image was Guardiola raising his eyes to the sky and howling in frustration while McFarlane celebrated a few feet away from him after Enzo Fernández’s deserved equalising goal deep into stoppage time.
Chelsea’s rookie coach outwits Guardiola to dent Man City title hopes
“Hang it in the Louvre”, as they say. Hopefully for McFarlane that image will have been captured by a photographer because whatever the 40-year-old goes on to achieve in his career he should always have that moment.
“It was amazing, stuff you dream about. Pep Guardiola, Premier League game, amazing,” McFarlane said afterwards.
And to think, also, that prior to joining Southampton, McFarlane was a youth team coach at Manchester City before, last week, being asked to step up from his role with Chelsea’s Under-21s to take the senior team following the abrupt departure of Enzo Maresca and his staff.
City will feel they threw it away – and their game management was questionable, while defensive injuries mount – but whatever the reason this was a highly damaging draw for them.
Following on from the midweek draw at Sunderland, they are now suddenly six points behind Arsenal who are beginning to have the relentless sheen and robustness of potential champions.
If that happens how they and Mikel Arteta will raise a toast to McFarlane who is expected to take Chelsea training tomorrow before handing over to Liam Rosenior who has flown in to London to seal his move from Strasbourg.
At times in the last few days it has felt that the Chelsea ownership believe they can operate the club without a head coach. Was this performance a confirmation of that?
No, it would do a huge disservice to McFarlane who showed some astute in-game management, shift of tactics and substitutions. His starting line-up looked defensive and when he withdrew Estêvão Willian at half-time and brought on Andrey Santos it appeared to be turning into an exercise in damage limitation with City 1-0 up, on top, having hit the post through Erling Haaland and created more chances.
Not so, as McFarlane explained afterwards. “They [City] had a lot of control and we were getting pinned back,” he said. “So, we made a change at half-time to go more man-for-man against the ball and disrupt their rhythm. The shape changed and the subs we made really helped us.”
It all worked. It meant Fernández – who scored of course – moved further forward with Cole Palmer switched to the right. When Liam Delap came on, replacing the ineffective João Pedro, there was also more running power to stretch City’s creaking defence which lost Josko Gvardiol and Rúben Dias to injury.
“We can talk about that but the most impressive thing was the players 1-0 down at the Etihad with an interim manager and with players going ill on the day of the game,” McFarlane added.
It was and he will also have the moment that Chelsea captain Reece James – outstanding in midfield, a response to those who claim the team does not have leaders – pushed him forward to take the acclaim from the travelling supporters.
To think how it had looked and sounded so different. Tijjani Reijnders had given City their first-half lead as they countered through Rodri and Rayan Cherki with the midfielder cleverly rolling his studs over the ball before striking a powerful rising shot beyond stand-in goalkeeper Filip Jorgensen.
At that time the main noise from the Chelsea fans had been chants of “Roman Abramovich” which felt like a protest against the current ownership and it appeared to be a question of just how many City would score.
It did not happen. They simply did not create enough and they did not show the ruthlessness of a side destined for the title. A second goal would have killed Chelsea’s resistance but instead they were encouraged with Pedro Neto sidefooting wastefully over, after Fernández set him up, and Delap forcing an alert block from Gianluigi Donnarumma.
By the time the board showed six minutes of added time Chelsea were the most likely to score and City were trying to run the clock down. Then Malo Gusto crossed low from the right, Donnarumma superbly parried Fernández’s first effort only for him to stab home the rebound.
The time was at 93 minutes and 14 seconds – almost precisely (just six seconds earlier) the same as that famous Sergio Agüero goal back in 2012. That delivered City’s first Premier League title. We cannot say that Fernández – a fellow Argentinian – did not score the goal that helped deny them another. Not yet anyway. But it may have a greater bearing come May.
City suffer double injury blow
Pep Guardiola’s title hopes have been hit with a double injury blow after Rúben Dias and Josko Gvardiol were forced off injured in the draw against Chelsea.
Guardiola’s first-choice centre-backs will be scanned on Monday to determine the extent of the damage suffered in the second half, with Manchester City dropping more points to lose ground on leaders Arsenal.
With John Stones already out and Nathan Aké unable to play matches in quick succession, Guardiola faces an injury crisis ahead of a crucial game against Brighton and Hove Albion on Wednesday.
“We’ll see but it doesn’t look good,” said Guardiola. “Him [Gvardiol] and Rúben, we’ll see what happens. With Rúben it looks like muscle. I didn’t speak to the doctor but if Rúben is out it’s because he felt something.”
Gvardiol was helped down the tunnel by two City staff as he was unable to put weight on his left ankle, while Dias was forced off with nine minutes left after feeling a strain off the ball.
“We have a lot [of injuries]. John Stones is missing for I don’t know how many months. Rúben now will be out, Josko will be out. Nathan, always we know with Nathan he cannot play regularly.
“It’s the situation. Stay strong and we will find a solution. The spirit is there and will be there. Of course I have concerns. Have you seen the bench today? Four players from the academy and now we will have more. We don’t have players.”
After Dias went off, Chelsea equalised in the 94th minute through Enzo Fernández, cancelling out Tijjani Reijnders’ strike. Despite the injury blows, Guardiola must decide whether he goes into the January market for a defender if they are out long-term.
“I don’t think so but we’ll see what happens because I know Rúben is a big loss and Josko is a big loss,” said the City manager.
‘This group is exceptional’: Chelsea interim manager Calum McFarlane’s reaction
“I think the main thing is for the three days we have worked with the players, they are open. They are hard-working, honest, they want to do the right things. I can’t speak about my changes more than them buying into it and applying what we wanted them to do. I thought they did that exceptionally well in the second half.”
“The group have been exceptional. As a [under] 21 staff coming in, we couldn’t ask for anything more. No egos, completely on board, training has been brilliant. Enzo, Reece, Tosin, in terms of their leadership and management of the group now the manager is gone and there is an interim in ... Levi, Cucu[rella], Moises, all here travelling even though they know they aren’t going to play.
The togetherness in the group is exceptional. That is why this group can win big games and big moments, they have done it again today. At 1-0 down at half-time, interim manager, players injured, everyone is expecting the worst. But the character this group has is why they can go and beat PSG, beat Barca, play with 10 men against Arsenal and be the better team, it’s why they can do this at the Etihad. They are an exceptional group of people.
[On whether the experience has given him a taste for this] Obviously I’m inexperienced, but I really enjoyed it. In the future, I would love to do that but at the moment, I love my role, my job. I’ve got a really good role at Chelsea, I am just here to support in the short-term until the new manager comes in and I’m glad I can do that and support the players.”
‘We had chances to close the game’: Pep Guardiola’s reaction
“One action and [they] score a goal. We had a lot of actions, we play a fantastic game, so pity for the result.
[On whether he was particularly pleased with the first 45 minutes] 90 minutes. 95. We played so good all game, it’s normal in the second half they make a step-up, they were more aggressive because normally Chelsea is not like that, they make a step-up, it was more difficult. We have two options in the beginning of the game because we lose easier balls with Tijjani [Reijnders] and Matheus [Nunes].
But the rest, we had chances in the right moment to close the game, in the end we couldn’t do it and when it went 1-0, anything can happen with the quality they had.
[How are Dias and Gvardiol?] It doesn’t look good, we’ll see the next days.
We knew when you have all the squad, you can compete and rotate. Right now, it’s the situation and we will have another energy to get back. I cannot change the [schedule ahead], it is where it is.”
Chelsea’s changes worked
Chelsea had eight shots in the match and seven came in the second half. Neto probably should have scored minutes after the restart. There were warning signs before Enzo’s late, late equaliser.
Callum McFarlane got the team playing in a more aggressive way and is unbeaten as a professional football manager.
‘We are in a difficult moment’: Reece James’s post-match reaction
“We had to accept what went on earlier in the week and put it behind us. We came here with a game plan, we know what level we can perform at when we are all together and all firing. The first half we made a slight error for their goal, but the second half, we grew into the game, knew a chance would come and this guy took his chance when it came.
Credit to the staff that stepped up. They haven’t been in this role before, to come to City away as your first first-team game is difficult. We had to adapt fast, the first half we felt they had too much of the ball, we had to make slight adjustments and came out with a slightly different plan in the second half.
We are in a difficult moment, we have to stand together, we are one. We missed many people that travelled today, but so many other players stepped up. We fought as a team today and I’m proud of the boys ... we dug in and got a point.
We know nothing at the moment [in terms of when a new manager comes in], this whole week was about this game. What happens behind the scenes is not down to us. We take a point at a really difficult place to come, we have to recover, we play again in a few days.”
90+6 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 1
Pep looks like he’s seen a ghost. City have wasted so many good positions, they have brought this on to themselves.
City were time-wasting and professional fouling before that Enzo equaliser. They deserved that late blow. Chelsea’s bench were pretty confident that all their players were onside, even if there was a VAR delay. With the unrestrained passion of the celebration, most would be glad the goal stood.
GOAL!
Man City 1 Chelsea 1 (Enzo) A late point-saver? From the free-kick James sends Gusto down the right and he storms round O’Reilly to cross. Ake slides in but only gets a toe on it and the ball spins towards the back post where Enzo has a couple of bites at it, thwarted at first by Donnarumma but then pokes it in.
90+2 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
Chelsea are looking to go long and James picks out Gusto’s run up the right. He beats Ake to the pass but then flops on to the floor as if hoping for a free-kick that does not come.
Haaland almost sent through with a scooped pass. Applause from the crowd, but Guardiola is going ballistic at his team. He saw that Jeremy Doku was free on the left and wanted a simple pass.
87 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
Chelsea just haven’t been good enough with their forward passes consistently even though City look as if they’re exhausted.
Ruben Dias coming off rather than Khusanov is a concern for City, who have struggled with injuries in that position. John Stones has been out and Gvardiol injured in this game. Interesting that Nathan Ake has been given minutes here after starting against Sunderland on Thursday. There have been Premier League clubs monitoring his situation, with the Sunderland start his first since October 18. Perhaps Guardiola is trying to keep him happy.
78 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
Delap shoves Kushanov into the advertising hoardings after the defender held him off in the box and shepherded the ball out for a goal-kick. Nunes, Dias and Bernardo go garrity with their former team-mate, banging chests and prodding him while Delap just smiles. Eventually Delap and Nunes are booked.
76 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
Groans echo around the Etihad after Doku’s glorious right-foot pass from the left sends Foden free down the wing. But with only one Chelsea defender between him and Cherki he is mortified to see Badiashile judging the pass perfectly to stop it reaching its target who would have been one-on-one with Jorgensen.
73 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
Delap rolls Khusanov in the box, latching on to Neto’s pass, to shoot. Khusanov slid in to block and the ball skipped up off his toe and Donnarumma managed to block it with the right side of his chest and biceps.
They know all about Liam Delap here at the Etihad Stadium. He probably would be playing for them today if it wasn’t for a certain Erling Haaland being at the club. That was a decent effort by the England hopeful, forcing a save from Gianluigi Donnarumma.
70 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
Fine City move. Donnarumma chips it up to Haaland who nods it down the right for Cherki. The No 10 glides into the box then squares it for Bernardo but didn’t get enough on the pass, allowing Hato the time to slide in and knock it away as Bernardo, with eyes widened, drew back his left foot to shoot.
Doku → Reijnders.
Reece James playing in central midfield for the last month has gone under the radar a bit. It is an option for Thomas Tuchel at the World Cup next year. James has had a decent afternoon, at the heart of Chelsea’s best moves forwards and positionally disciplined. He has picked up a booking, which was slightly unfortunate for a follow-through that he could do little about.
City have defended well so far when Chelsea have got into a decent positions. McFarlane has his team playing in a more attacking way now, with Liam Delap up front and getting support from Pedro Neto and Cole Palmer.
64 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
A couple of careless Chelsea passes almost let Haaland and Cherki in but first Hato and then Badiashile sweep up the mess.
Abdukodir Khusanov is making just his second Premier League appearance since Sept 21 when he was taken off at half-time against Arsenal. He has slotted straight in at centre-back alongside Ruben Dias. But while Pep Guardiola has not been using him regularly, the City manager still rates last January’s signings – including Khusanov – as season-saving. Without them, City would be playing in the Europa Conference League, according to Guardiola.
52 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
Reece James helps Gvardiol, who has hurt his ankle, off.
Khusanov → Gvardiol.
Chelsea are playing 3-4-2-1 with Gusto and Pedro Neto as wing-backs and Palmer and Enzo behind Joao Pedro.
James is booked for following through on Rodri and catching him on the top of the foot with his studs.
49 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
Neto scoops a shot over from eight yards. Had to score. Chelsea had broken after Gvardiol went down and had a 4v3 overload. Palmer and Enzo did very well to break into the box and then Enzo gift-wrapped the opportunity that Pedro Neto squandered.
City are not particularly happy with that Chelsea chance as Josko Gvardiol was down injured as Pedro Neto shot over. He is still getting treatment.
In fact, the tackle from Malo Gusto was strong enough for Gvardiol to come off. He is being helped by two members of the City staff down the tunnel for treatment.
47 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
Pedro Neto is played down the left by Enzo’s clever dink past Cherki. He sprints away from Nunes and has time and space to shoot but decides to go up a cul de sac near the byline and cut the ball back. Only Joao Pedro was with him and he was surrounded so the ball deflects off Dias and is easily caught by Donnarumma.
Half-time: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
A strange half, dominated by City in terms of possession and touches in the opposition box but Chelsea, James and Gusto in particularly, were defending very well. But there was no outlet for them when they did win the ball back and seemed resigned to sitting back and trying to repel each wave of attack. For most of the half Cuty’s exertions were undone by a lack of precision and some overplaying. And then Reijnders seized his chance by the slack of its collar and smashed in the opener.
44 min: Man City 1 Chelsea 0
It may have been coming but Chelsea had a hand in it when Palmer lost the ball in a promising position 30 yards from goal on a rare foray up front.
That goal had many different faces of City. Rodri was at the heart of it - just touching the ball to Cherki for him to set up the move. When the ball broke for Tijjani Reinders, there was the option to find Haaland but the Dutch midfielder rolled his studs over the ball to make a yard of space and finish. This will be tough going now for Chelsea. Maybe a change at half-time to get Garnacho in the game.
40 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
The corner comes to naught but City regroup to attack down the left with O’Reilly challenging James, illegally according to Gary Neville, switching it across to the inside right to Haaland who steps in on to his left, in that old familiar way, and raps a shot on to the inside of the left post. It rebounds across the six-yard line and away from danger.
38 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
City corner after Haaland’s left-foot shot from 18 yards hits Badiashile’s heel as he knelt to block and wobbles towards goal. Jorgensen dives to his left to turn it behind.
City are getting closer here. Erling Haaland has just had an effort tipped around the post and then struck the woodwork, while Bernardo Silva cleared the crossbar after cutting inside. McFarlane’s tactic is to get men behind the ball. Yes, they are a flat-back four but Reece James and Josh Acheampong sitting in front of them means they can stretch out with five or six across the backline.
36 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
Bernardo has a stuttering run in from the left as he stops to try to shake off Gusto before starting again, feinting left and right, but Gusto doesn’t give up and stalks him all the way unil Bernardo reaches the right of the D and tries to bend a left-foot shot into the top corner around the left-back which sails out for a goal-kick. Too straight. Not enough curve.
34 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
James again smells the danger of a City pass or cross and snuffs it out with excellent positioning. He’s such a fine player. Has to be England’s starting right-back if he stays fit. Nunes’ cute pass to Cherki doesn’t come off but Gusto, safety first, lumps the ball forward to Donnarumma rather than risk a square pass. No runners off Joao Pedro as it’s all hands to the pump in defence.
29 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
Good defending from Badiashile to track Haaland’s run and compete for the cross stood up by Reijnders on the run from the left. Badiashile gets enough brow on it to squeeze it behind for a corner which, again, Chelsea defend solidly.
This is tighter than expected this game. Chelsea are playing quite well, breaking forward at times and seeing a decent effort from Estevao blocked in the penalty area. Nothing too much from City yet and Pep Guardiola is clearly not happy - he made his feelings clear during a conversation with Josko Gvardiol.
20 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
City break from that block with a wonderful diagonal pass from Nunes out to Reijnders on the left. The Holland midfielder rattles over a pass to the right of the D that Foden cushions beautifully with his right to wrongfoot Gusto and allow him to throw his balance on to his left to shoot but he screws his effort about a yard wide.
16 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
The Chelsea fans, like their City counterparts, must be frozen but Estevao is enough to warm the Baltic Sea and his promising but ultimately ineffective run down the right triggers a chorus of ‘Chelsea, Chelsea, Chelsea!’
Gary Neville says the game is tranquil. The players look knackered… and still one more round of ‘festive’ fixtures to come on Wednesday.
11 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
Enzo lazily throws out an arm to try to stop Cherki rather than engaging after jockeying him and leaves James exposed as City’s No 10 runs off ahead after brushing Fernandez away. James sticks his leg across Cherki in full flight and concedes the free-kick, right of centre, 25 yards out.
5 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
Jorgensen pumps the ball 70 yards having spotted Gusto’s clever run infield but so did Donnarumma and he bounded out of his box to head the bouncing ball to a team-mate and City turn defence into attack. Sleet falling now. Reijnders is penalised for a push and that’s the end of that.
3 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
Dias holds off Gusto and lets the ball run out for a throw-in. Nunes’ pass inside from the right, looking for Bernardo, is picked off by Enzo Fernandez. Bernardo sticks with him and blocks his cross, turning it behind for a corner from which Joao Pedro is penalised for a foul on Donnarumma.
1 min: Man City 0 Chelsea 0
Cole Palmer kicks off for Chelsea and knocks the ball straight back to Jorgensen who targets the right wing. Reijnders, who is playing on the left, picks it up and drives forward but can’t retain possession.
The Etihad Stadium just paid an “In Memoriam” to those associated with Manchester City and Chelsea who passed away in 2025. No bigger cheer than for Ricky Hatton when his name was read out.
The teams are out
City are in sky blue and white, Chelsea in their home strip of royal blue and white.
A quick reminder of the line-ups:
Man City Donnarumma; Nunes, Dias, Gvardiol, O’Reilly; Rodri, Bernardo, Reijnders; Cherki, Foden; Haaland.
Substitutes Trafford, Ake, Doku, Khusanov, McAidoo, Mukasa, Lewis, Mfuni, R Heskey.
Chelsea Jorgensen; Acheampong, Chalobah, Badiashile, Gusto; James, Fernandez; Estevao, Palmer, Pedro Neto; Joao Pedro.
Substitutes Garnacho, Guiu, Hato, Santos, Bynoe-Gittens, Delap, Adarabioyo, Merrick, Slonina.
Referee Michael Oliver (Ashington).
Calum McFarlane speaks to Sky Sports
I’m feeling good, calm. We’ve had some good days training, good prep and the lads are in a good place. We’ve just tried to get the feeling in the group right. It’s always hard when a manager leaves. We’ve tried to pick them up socially and emotionally and I think they’re ready. You have to find the balance, get the feeling right and the emotion right so the lads are in a good place and I think we’ve done a good job over the last few days.
Blog exclusive!
Manchester City centre-back Jahmai Simpson-Pusey, 20, is undergoing a medical at German club Cologne ahead of a loan move to the Bundlesliga outfit. The England Under-20 international was at Celtic for the first half of the season but returned from his loan after finding first-team opportunities difficult.
On the Chelsea line-up
Chelsea caretaker boss Calum McFarlane has made a big call dropping Alejandro Garnacho from his starting line-up. There is a forced change as Robert Sanchez was injured on the eve of the match so Filip Jorgensen starts his first Premier League game. He came off the bench at the start of the season when Sanchez was sent off against Manchester United.
Rodri starts for City
There were a few flakes of snow on the east side if Manchester. It is bitterly cold here for Chelsea’s first match since the departure of Enzo Maresca. As one ex-Chelsea player pointed out in the press room, it is a cup final for Calum McFarlane – if the caretaker boss can win here, he could get another game in charge. Liam Rosenior is expected to get the nod.
Rodri starts for Man City. It is his first start since October, when he was injured against Brentford and then suffered a setback on his comeback.
Preview: Maestro vs novice
Good evening and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League match between Manchester City and Chelsea, the teams that started the day in third and sixth. City, unbeaten in seven though their six-match winning steak in the Premier League was abruptly ended when they hit the wall, and the rock of Sunderland’s defence at home, on New Year’ Day, can narrow Arsenal’s lead to four points with victory today and given they have beaten Chelsea six times and drawn once on their last seven visits in league and cup to the Etihad, they would be pretty confident of doing so even if Chelsea were not rocking up with a novice caretaker manager.
Calum McFarlane, who stepped up when Enzo Maresca found a couple of bootprints across the seat of his pants five days ago, joins a lengthy list of Chelsea interims over the past 15 years, following Roberto Di Matteo, Rafa Benítez, Steve Holland, Guus Hiddink in a second stint, Bruno Saltor and Frank Lampard in taking temporary control. Of those six only Lampard lost his first game in charge (again in a second stint), going down 2-0 to Real Madrid and then by the same score against Brentford at Stamford Bridge if you think judging him by defeat against the champions of Europe is too harsh.
The Under-21 head coach, who has worked at Southampton and Man City after a few years working at Kinetic Academy, is without long-term absentees Levi Colwill, Roméo Lavia, Mykhailo Mudryk and Jorrel Hato while Moises Caicedo is suspended. Chelsea, looking to improve a run of one win, four draws and two defeats in Maresca’s last seven games, may also be lacking Marc Cucurella who has a thigh strain.
City have two players away at the Africa Cup of Nations, Rayan Aït-Nouri and Omar Marmoush, and three recovering from injury in Oscar Bobb, John Stones and Mateo Kovacic. Savinho and Nico González were hurt during the draw with Sunderland but have not been definitively ruled out.

headline: Leicester’s all-English back line smash sorry Saracens
body: Leicester’s all-English back line smash sorry Saracens
content:
On a frozen Leicester night, bringing down the curtain on a chilly festive period that left referee Matthew Carley requiring gloves to stay warm, one might have been forgiven for thinking that the Tigers would stick to tradition and grind out a performance of grit and gumption in front of a sold-out Welford Road. Think again.
This handsome Leicester victory, with a bonus point sewn up before half-time, owed as much to the artists behind the pack as the artisans within it. Billy Searle and Will Wand were wonderful for Leicester in that punchy first-half showing but Freddie Steward, Adam Radwan – scorers of three Tigers tries between them – and Ollie Hassell-Collins all played their part, too. Jack van Poortvliet, on his first start since October, was sharp at scrum-half and Orlando Bailey, one of English rugby’s forgotten prospects, had his best game in a Leicester shirt at inside centre. Wand, certainly, was the best player on the park in the opening 40 minutes but the return of Emeka Ilione, the back row on England’s radar, gave the centre stiff competition after half-time.

headline: Man Utd and Amorim cannot go on like this after latest crisis
body: Man Utd and Amorim cannot go on like this after latest crisis
content:
Ruben Amorim says the loss of Bruno Fernandes, Bryan Mbeumo and Amad Diallo has decimated Manchester United’s creativity.
Fernandes is currently sidelined with a hamstring injury while Mbeumo and Amad are away at the Africa Cup of Nations with Cameroon and Ivory Coast respectively.
The trio have together created 105 chances for United in the Premier League this season, which is almost as many chances (122) as the rest of the team have created combined.
United survived sustained second half pressure to beat Newcastle on Boxing Day but could only draw 1-1 to bottom club Wolves at Old Trafford on Tuesday when they looked well short of ideas going forward.
With Mason Mount also out now after being substituted at half-time against Newcastle, Amorim says United have lost the vast majority of their creativity.
“I don’t like to talk about that [the lack of depth], it sounds like an excuse,” the United manager said ahead of the trip to Elland Road to face Leeds on Sunday. “[But] it was bad luck to lose Amad, Bryan, especially, and Bruno at the same time.
“They had more creation in the opportunities than the rest of the team. If you lose the three of them at the same time, any team in the world will struggle. And now Mount.
“You have all the data and you can sense that three guys create most of the chances for us. And if you lose not one but all three at the same time, of course we are going to struggle.”
Amorim said the impact was being felt not just from open play but also from set-pieces. “Then you have to put set pieces in that. Who is kicking the set pieces? Amad, Bryan and Bruno,” he said. “So everything is combined and we just need to acknowledge that.
“The important thing is to understand why we struggled in the last three games in creation and quality in the game. I think it’s clear.”
With eight senior players missing through injury and the Afcon Amorim said it was “impossible” for anyone to leave this month as things stand. Joshua Zirkzee, Kobbie Mainoo and Manuel Ugarte all face uncertain futures.
“If you look at our squad, I think it’s impossible for someone to leave,” Amorim said. “But that is … they need to talk with Jason [Wilcox, the director of football].”
Amorim had suggested on Christmas Eve, prior to the Newcastle game, that he was not necessarily going to get the time and money required to play the “perfect 3-4-3” and as such was needing to adapt his system. “I have the feeling that if we have to play a perfect 3-4-3, we need to spend a lot of money and we need time,” he said. “So, I’m starting to understand that that is not going to happen so maybe I have to adapt.”
But Amorim was reluctant to discuss those remarks in further detail ahead of the Leeds match. “I don’t want to talk about that. I just focus on the Leeds game,” he said.
Asked if he regretted making those comments, Amorim added: “No, no, no. But I don’t want to talk about it. I don’t want to talk about that. Okay … You are very smart, so…”

headline: Brentford’s Igor Thiago might just be the league’s best striker not called Erling Haaland
body: Brazilian was back among the goals with a hat-trick at Everton where Keith Andrews’ team continued their impressive campaign
content:
Everton should be looking to emulate Brentford’s canny recruitment off the pitch. Thiago cost marginally more than Barry or Beto but has scored nine more league goals than the pair combined and organised yet effective on it.
The fact Kevin Schade opted for Brentford when there was interest from Everton two summers ago showed how low the club’s reputation had dropped in the wake of off-field financial problems and several relegation battles.
But even taking into account a threadbare squad, manager David Moyes is not getting value for money from a number of individuals while suffering a heavy defeat on a day when both his under-performing strikers scored.
Jack Grealish, on loan from Manchester City, provided both assists and would have had another in first-half added time had Caoimhin Kelleher not kept out Barry’s diving header, but with Kiernan Dewsbury-Hall injured and Iliman Ndiaye at the Africa Cup of Nations the burden is all on him to carry the attacking threat.
The £40m spent on 19-year-old Tyler Dibling, making his third consecutive start, was a punt on potential when they need proven performers while James Tarkowski, whose mistake led to the opening goal before he was beaten to a corner for the second, is also looking less than reliable.
Everton’s two early chances saw Dwight McNeil denied by Kelleher and Thiago clear Tarkowski’s header off the line, but they then shot themselves in the foot.
Tarkowski’s pass to Tim Iroegbunam was weak and ill-advised as the midfielder was sandwiched between Schade and Vitaly Janelt, and the latter seized the ball and crossed for Thiago to cushion a low volley past Jordan Pickford.

headline: Spurs booed off again as pressure mounts on beleaguered Frank
body: Spurs booed off again as pressure mounts on beleaguered Frank
content:
Damned by his tactics, style and now by the timing of a transfer, Thomas Frank found his travails as Tottenham manager supplemented by a deserved late Brian Brobbey equaliser for Sunderland at Tottenham Hotspur Stadium.
Had the home side held on for a narrow 1-0 victory courtesy of Ben Davies’s scruffy first-half goal, the home fans would have grudgingly accepted another staccato performance by their team.
The problem was that they did not hold on. Frank seemed to be outmanoeuvred by his Sunderland counterpart Régis Le Bris whose substitutions were imaginatively deployed and impeccably timed, and a solitary point was greeted by a chorus of boos at the final whistle, seemingly directed in the main towards the Tottenham manager.
Frank was not helped by a 19th-minute injury to Mohammed Kudus which only served to highlight the decision of the club to sanction Brennan Johnson’s transfer to Crystal Palace last week.

headline: Newcastle start ‘season-defining month’ with ugly win over Crystal Palace
body: Newcastle start ‘season-defining month’ with ugly win over Crystal Palace
content:
Newcastle United remain a riddle we are not yet able to answer, but on a subdued, flat afternoon on a bitterly cold Tyneside, they dragged themselves to a hugely important victory over Crystal Palace.
It was the win they needed at the start of what manager Eddie Howe has described as a “season-defining month” for his team, but it was, at times, a patchy and ugly performance.
In fact, it was a strange game, played in an odd atmosphere as the return to work after the Christmas holidays loomed large. The stadium was quiet at times. Annoyed at others. There have been too many unconvincing performances over the last few months for blind optimism to fuel the home crowd.
But the fans ultimately played their part in the end, helping roar their team on to a late flourish and a win that puts them firmly back in the European qualification hunt.
Newcastle struggled to get into a rhythm, the home crowd were irritable and restless as passes went astray and promising moves broke down.
But the players kept going and eventually battered the Palace defence enough to score two second-half goals.
At the heart of things, hustling and bustling in midfield, winning the ball on the ground and in the air was Joelinton. The Brazil international has struggled with groin problems this season and was rested in December. His return to form and fitness has been integral to both victories against Burnley and Palace.
